specs/rocky/approved/metrics-retention.r.message: Determination/setting of metrics retention should consider things like Functional area, metric granularity/time interval, roll-up policy. Essentially we want to enable the admin/user to be able to dump any metrics that are no longer relevant to their operations

These use cases seem to focus on how the data was collected. We should be looking to enable setting retention policy on groups of similarly behaving metrics. This could either be predefined groups of metrics or adhoc groupings defined by the admin. As noted above, this would be more driven by things like the collection interval (metrics collected every 60 seconds are not real relevant after 3 months), type of metric, class of metric, ...
So is this optional property support for cases where the submitter wants to override an policy based retention period?

Having a seperate mechanism to configure retention based on the fact that it is collected somewhere else is not really great. I would prefer a more central policy

This will prevent setting values which might include a comma, like -e abc=def,ghi

Can we pass in a list instead? There's already a branch which should be handling a list below.
Ack on the IR limitation, thanks for the context.

The idea of this parameter is to pass file locations to append into the upgrade_prepare command, so you won't find a comma in a directory location. The list is being covered in line 58 though. But this is a special case in which we can't pass a list (for example due to infrared's limitation that even though we pass a list, the whole parameter's value will be converted into a string) so this is a simple solution, pass multiple files in the string separating them by comma. upgrade_prepare_extra_params="/home/stack/file1.yaml,/home/stack/file2.yaml,/home/stack/file3.yaml"

yes, but is there a dependency between worker and healthmanager? 
I mean worker won't work properly until health-manager started.

But as I looked at the worker log in my testbed, the worker didn't seem to use o-hm until I actually created openstack loadbalancer. 
So I didn't care. 
From this point of view, how about create o-hm on each controller before deployment (ex. 180-create-resource-for-octavia.sh)?
both hm and worker use host network. At once hm initialize o-hm0 nic, worker can see it. So it works well.

Several octavia components like worker, healt-manager and housekeeping require access to LB management network (more infor might be found here https://docs.openstack.org/octavia/stein/contributor/guides/dev-quick-start.html#install-octavia-controller-software).
At the same time non of mentioned processes have strict requirement to be launched as single instance on the physical host (for example neutron openvwitch agent or nova-compute have this requirement as they modify network settings (ovs) or manage qemu domains). Octavia only needed access to LB network, and it is completely safe to run several instances of workers on the same host.
Access to LB network might be done in different ways:
1. By using external physnets in neutron (drawback is that it will require additional vlan, or physical interface on hardware host)
2. By using one of tenant networks (using openvswitch agent to bind (plug) octavia port in-to the neutron lb network).
3. Setup lb network in the same way as floating network is configured.

IMO we shouldn't use daemon set here to allow having multiple workers running on the same host.

I don't think the above 2 lines are correct.  They build a list of only realtime controllers, and then all() will return true if there are any controllers in that list.  This means that all_realtime will be True in the scenario where you have a mix of realtime and non-realtime controllers (BOSS+PERC).
I think you want something like:
all_realtime = all(cntlr['is_reboot_required]'] == "optional" for cntlr in controllers)
I believe the above will create a list that contains 1 boolean value per controller indicating if the controller supports realtime.  all() will then return True only if all controllers support realtime.

I think we can remove the call to _filter_controllers() since the race condition will be removed by not running any jobs in realtime mode if there are some controllers that don't support realtime mode.

ironic/drivers/modules/drac/management.p.message:
Hi Chris, I have implemented above changes locally,
but before updating patch, I would like to ask you one question, 

I think, "pending bios config job" should be cleared in all the cases(whenever set_boot_device() is called) to handle error's like below:
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1534551

And "pending non-bios config job" should be cleared whenever 'clear_job_queue' or 'known_good_state' clean step exists in node like below: 

if node.driver_internal_info.get("clean_steps")[0].get(
     'step') in ['clear_job_queue', 'known_good_state']:
      # then delete only non-bios unfinished jobs.

Is it correct approach??  or
can we simply delete all the unfinished jobs, whenever 'clear_job_queue' or 'known_good_state clean step exists in node as you suggested??
Hi Chris, I have resolved this comment in updated patch, please review it.

Hey Pradip, you make a very good point that we should delete all the unfinished jobs if either the known_good or the clear_job_queue cleaning steps are being executed, and I completely agree with that.  I think it makes perfect sense to delete the pending jobs when we are in the process of running a cleaning step that will clear the job queue, since the user clearly just wants the job queue cleared and almost certainly does not want any pending jobs to run.  If the user is not running a cleaning step that will clear the job queue though, I think it is less obvious if it's expected behavior to delete all pending jobs.  I think I would be conservative and say that we should not delete pending jobs in this case and error out instead.  It should be best practice for the user to put the server into the known good state by running the known_good cleaning step prior to starting to work with the iDRAC.  If this is done, then they shouldn't run into the case where there are pending unfinished jobs.  If they do hit the case where there are pending unfinished jobs, then it will be due to a bug in the calling code, a bug in our code, or a firmware bug.  If it is due to a bug in our code or the firmware, we would want them to file a bug ticket so that we are aware of it and can fix the bug.  Always deleting pending jobs would hide this situation instead of making it evident, so I don't think we should do that.
Could you put a check around this so we only validate the job queue if we didn't just delete all of the unfinished jobs?

Could you simplify this a little and at line 199, before the "if" statement:
validate_job_queue = True

Then at line 205, inside the 3rd "if" statement and just before delete_jobs():
validate_job_queue = False

Then this "if" statement becomes a simple:
if validate_job_queue:

That test would test when set_boot_device is called and the clear_job_queue cleaning step is running like it is here. Okay, sorry, I had to re-figure this all back out. I had this looked up for Artom week before last and took notes, but it's obscure and fell out of my head. So, the lock you've linked to is a lock on the filename that will become the root disk of the instance being created. Since we're not doing that here, we have no such name to lock on. Further, two instance being booted at the same time that have the same image would be locked on their respective target disk names, not the common base image they both are about to try to fetch.

The actual place where they synchronize is in images.fetch() on compute_utils.disk_ops_semaphore:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/9a9d412ef8863d694736da1ba7247a0f47578bf9/nova/virt/images.py#L142

which is a layer under fetch_to_raw() that I'm calling here. So, we're generating a stable temp name (${image}.part) and then grabbing the semaphore before we ask the image_api to download to that filename. It must fail if the file exists when it goes to open it, otherwise we'd race when booting lots of instances from the same image today.

I can go check that image code to make sure it's doing what the existing code thinks it is, but at the end of the day, this is doing the same thing that spawn is.

Modelling 4K pages in placement isn't sufficient if we allow instances with 4K pages that are restricted to a NUMA node on the same host as instances with 4K pages that float across the whole host.  (Because then we don't know which NUMA node the floating instance allocated memory from.)

In order to have accurate modelling in placement either we treat 4K pages as a whole-host resource rather than a per-NUMA-node one, or else we restrict instances with 4K pages to a single NUMA node.

The former option has the advantage of being backwards-compatible.  The latter option might offer more performance, but will almost certainly cause problems for someone with existing floating instances that don't fit on the available resources of a single NUMA node.

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo-kernel/var.message:
just reading through the bug... looks like by loading that module we get the right settings at net.bridge.bridge-nf-call-iptables etc... my question is why don't we just set those values we want below as we are doing for all the other things, rather than loading an extra module 

if the error was like "modprobe fatal br_netfilter not found" ok but this is about loading it so it sets some config values for us.

Unless its something like even if we set them they will be overridden unless we load that module?

The kernel default is 1. They are overriden in /usr/lib/sysctl.d/00-system.conf to 0. When the kernel boots w/o br_netfilter in modules-load.d, the values stay the kernel default of 1--until something like a systemctl network restart happens and then it will flip to 0 (with the fun side effect of disabling all security groups silently). So by loading the module we go from getting the *right* settings at boot to the *wrong* settings, but we need the module loaded so we can set the *right* settings *all* of the time.

Haha, yes - I had some comment thread confusion.

I'll update this to state that the 'baremetal:node:list" target defaults to "rule:baremetal:node:get", which should address the problem Dmitry pointed out.

Having a policy check per node sounds like it could be expensive. Note that I address updating the node get_all function in the next bullet point.

I'm unsure how to do that while still maintaining backwards compatibility. The closest I can think of is exposing 'baremetal:node:list' to everyone, and having 'get_all' do the filtering; is there an alternative you'd suggest?

I'd prefer to remove this plan completely, since I don't think it's correct, and I don't want to hold up this spec discussing allocations.

I actually seem to have a plan to handle them though (not necessary as part of this spec):

1. Add `allocation.owner` (as here)

2. Create a new policy baremetal:allocation:set_owner (defaulting to is_admin). If it's true, an owner can be set explicitly or left None. If false - owner is forcibly set to the caller project ID.

3. Modify allocation processing (in the conductor) to take owner in account, if set (i.e. make sure that `allocation.owner is None or allocation.owner == node.owner`).

Then to enable allocations for non-admin users it will be enough to allow them baremetal:allocation:create without touching baremetal:allocation:set_owner.

This seems simple enough for a follow-up RFE.

It turned out that the list returned by get_applications() is a list of active apps. The kube_app_get_all() in sysinv/db/sqlalchemy/api.py filtered out these that are "in-active":

    def kube_app_get_all(self):
        query = model_query(models.KubeApp)
        query = query.filter(
            models.KubeApp.status != constants.APP_INACTIVE_STATE)
        return query.all()

And convert_with_links() in sysinv/api/controllers/v1/kube_app.py removed "active" from the response:

    def convert_with_links(cls, rpc_app, expand=True):
        app = KubeApp(**rpc_app.as_dict())
        if not expand:
            app.unset_fields_except(['name', 'app_version', 'manifest_name',
                                     'manifest_file', 'status', 'progress'])

So I just need to remove the checking on app.status here.

> This check is incorrect - the app.status will change if the
 > application is being re-applied. You need to check the app.active
 > instead.

The app.active is in sysinv DB but not returned from get_applications. And if the app is being re-applied (thus the app.status changes), stx-openstack services is not supposed to be synced. Are there cases where app.status is "applied" but app.active is "False"?

grafana/templates/deployment.yaml.message: Could this cause issues if a user ends up with a large number of dashboard/panel snapshots that are set to never expire? Using an emptyDir here seems a bit risky - do we have alternatives, or are we just simply trusting people to do the right thing?  From what I'm seeing, the default expiration for snapshots seems to be Never
I checked it by draining and cordoning node which runs statefulset pod and it was rescheduled to another node. K8s viersion 1.13.2.

The grafana database only uses the emptydir at /var/lib/grafana/data when the database type is set to sqlite3 - the chart's database type default is set to mysql (mariadb in our case), so the emptydir here shouldn't be used in this case.

In the past, I've noticed occasional crashes during Grafana's startup when deploying multiple replicas - these crashes are almost always a result of multiple Grafana replicas trying to update the backing database at the same time.  One of the solutions I toyed around with was moving Grafana to a statefulset to enforce sequential startup to avoid those types of crashes.  That would also address the solution you mentioned - allowing us to back the snapshot directory with a PVC instead of an emptydir.  The only downside I see is that older versions of Kubernetes don't support the rescheduling of statefulsets if the node they're scheduled to becomes unavailable.  I'm wondering if that's something to be concerned about here or not
I think I can change this chart to use persistentVolume as a default volume type with an option to change it to emptyDir. Will it be right approach?

But I see that volumeClaimTemplates is used only with stateful set, so maybe it is not best decision to make it with grafana. And regarding never expiring snapshots, default value of expiration can not be changed via script or API request so we should trust people to do the right thing. By the way current version (with Grafana 5.0.0) stores snapshots in grafana.db which is placed in /var/lib/grafana/data which is an emptyDir.

After thinking about this some more,  this introduces a new problem.  If we're transitioning Grafana to a statefulset and using a PVC with a RWO access mode, it means each Grafana replica will store snapshots it takes in the PV allocated for that replicas claim.  When a user then attempts to access or view those snapshots, there is no guarantee that their request will be routed to the Grafana instance that has the desired snapshot(s) stored (stated differently, there is no mechanism for ensuring each Grafana replica has a copy of snapshots that are taken).
I think that the purpose of this change request is to update grafana version, not to make it scalable.
